quoteLast: , the ice passing the ship awoke me, and the door of my cabin, from the pressure, opened.  I hurriedly put on my clothes, and on getting on deck found some hands on the ice endeavouring to save the boats; but the latter were instantly crushed to pieces.
title: The Ocean and Its Wonders
author: Ballantyne, R. M. (Robert Michael), 1825-1894

quoteLast: ," remarked Malcolm Sage coolly, as he glanced at his wrist-watch.
title: Malcolm Sage, Detective
author: Jenkins, Herbert George, 1876-1923

quoteFirst: The Skipper walked for a little way, which did him good. Lunched as usual. Pace good. After lunch going good. Arrived at Safety Camp
quoteLast: To our delight found the sea-ice in the same condition and arrived at Hut Point at 7 o’clock. Found Hayward still about same. Set to, made a good dinner, and all hands seem in the best of spirits.
title: South: The Story of Shackleton's Last Expedition, 1914-1917
author: Shackleton, Ernest Henry, Sir, 1874-1922

quoteFirst: This first note invited us for a date three months in the future.  It asked us to arrive by the
quoteLast: train from London, August 6th.  The carriage would be waiting.  The carriage would take us away seven days later-train specified.
title: Following the Equator: A Journey Around the World
author: Twain, Mark, 1835-1910

quoteFirst: Shells began to be fired from the enemy, who closed. The British submarine saw the shots falling but could not see the enemy until
quoteLast: , when the German was descried to starboard of the _Prize_. There was a considerable lop on at the time, and _Prize_ was seen with White Ensign flying at the peak, and her guns manned.
title: Q-Ships and Their Story
author: Chatterton, E. Keble (Edward Keble), 1878-1944

title: The Papers and Writings of Abraham Lincoln — Volume 6: 1862-1863
author: Lincoln, Abraham, 1809-1865; Lapsley, Arthur Brooks [Editor]

quoteLast: . Prasville’s secretary, who had received his chief’s instructions by telephone, showed them into the office and asked them to wait. It was a quarter to five.
title: The Crystal Stopper
author: Leblanc, Maurice, 1864-1941

quoteFirst: The British squadron did not exceed nine ships of the line; the enemy’s fleet consisted of eleven; but they had still a greater advantage in number of men and artillery. Both squadrons fought with great impetuosity till about
quoteLast: , when the enemy’s rear began to give way: this example was soon followed by their centre; and finally the van, with the whole squadron, bore to the south-south-east, with all the canvass they could spread. The British squadron was so much damaged in their masts and rigging, that they could not pursue; so that M. d’Apché retreated at his leisure unmolested.
title:
The History of England in Three Volumes, Vol.II.
Continued from the Reign of William and Mary to the Death of George II.
author: Smollett, T. (Tobias), 1721-1771

quoteFirst: The testimony of Mrs. Frances Cason was taken at
quoteLast: , on April 1, 1964, in the office of the U.S. attorney, 301 Post Office Building, Bryan and Ervay Streets, Dallas, Tex., by Mr. Leon D. Hubert, Jr.
title: Warren Commission (13 of 26): Hearings Vol. XIII (of 15)
author: United States. Warren Commission
